title: LIDETA SUB CITY ADMINISTRATION EDUCATION OFFICE GRADE 12 CHEMISTRY MODEL EXAMINATIONS 2016E.C/ 2024G.C

questions.text: Which of the following branches of chemistry involves separating, identifying and determining the relative amount of a sample of matter?
questions.explanation: Analytical chemistry involves separating, identifying, and determining the relative amount of a sample of matter.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct?
questions.explanation: 1 liter is equal to 1 cubic decimeter.

questions.text: A piece of silver metal weighing 160 g is placed in a graduated cylinder containing 220 ml of water. The volume of water now reads 240 ml. What is the density of the silver metal?
questions.explanation: The density of the silver metal is calculated as mass/volume = 160g / (240ml - 220ml) = 160g / 20ml = 8.0 g/ml.

questions.text: What is the first step of the scientific method?
options: Predicting the result of an experiment
questions.explanation: The first step of the scientific method is making an observation.

questions.text: A student uses a digital balance (¬± 0.01), a thermometer (¬± 0.02), a measuring cylinder (¬± 0.03) and a beaker (¬± 0.04) during an experiment. Which of the above instruments is more precise?
questions.explanation: The digital balance is the most precise with a precision of ¬± 0.01.

questions.text: Which of the following postulates of Dalton‚Äôs atomic theory is disproved by the modern atomic theory?
options: Atoms combine in small whole numbers to form compounds
Elements are made up of small particles called atoms
Atoms of different elements have different masses and sizes
All atoms of the same elements are identical and have the same mass
questions.explanation: The modern atomic theory disproves that all atoms of the same element are identical and have the same mass.

questions.text: The main purpose of Robert Millikan‚Äôs oil drop experiment is to determine
options: The ratio of mass of electron to charge of electron
The magnitude of charge of electron
questions.explanation: The main purpose of Robert Millikan‚Äôs oil drop experiment is to determine the magnitude of the charge of an electron.

questions.text: Pb has an average atomic mass of 207.19 amu. The three major isotopes of Pb-206 (205.98 amu), Pb-207 (206.98 amu) and Pb-208 (207.98 amu). If the isotopes of Pb-207 and Pb-208 are present in equal amounts, what is the percent abundance of Pb-206, Pb-207 and Pb-208 respectively?
questions.explanation: The percent abundance of Pb-206, Pb-207, and Pb-208 can be calculated using the average atomic mass and the masses of the isotopes.

questions.text: Which region of the electromagnetic spectrum is capable of inducing electron transition with the greatest energy?
questions.explanation: Violet light has the highest energy in the visible spectrum and can induce electron transitions with the greatest energy.

questions.text: What is the wavelength of the yellow sodium emission, which has a frequency of 5.09 x 10¬π‚Å¥ s‚Åª¬π? (C = 3 x 10‚Å∏ m/s)
questions.explanation: The wavelength Œª can be calculated using the formula Œª = c/f = (3 x 10‚Å∏ m/s) / (5.09 x 10¬π‚Å¥ s‚Åª¬π) = 589 nm.

questions.text: What are the possible values of the azimuthal quantum number for an electron in the 4f subshell?
questions.explanation: The azimuthal quantum number (l) for an electron in the 4f subshell can have values from 0 to 3.

questions.text: How many 3d electrons are present in the ground state of 52Cr?
questions.explanation: The ground state electron configuration of 52Cr is [Ar] 3d‚Å¥ 4s¬≤, so there are 4 electrons in the 3d subshell.

questions.text: All of the following properties of an element increase across a period. EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Atomic size decreases across a period due to the increasing nuclear charge pulling the electrons closer to the nucleus.

questions.text: All of the following is the properties of ionic compounds in the solid phase. EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Ionic compounds in the solid phase do not have high electrical conductivity.

questions.text: Which of the following ionic compounds has the highest lattice energy?
questions.explanation: MgO has the highest lattice energy due to the high charge and small size of the ions.

questions.text: Which one of the substances contains ionic, covalent and dative bonds between their atoms?
questions.explanation: NH‚ÇÑCN contains ionic, covalent, and dative bonds.

questions.text: All of the following molecules is an example of a polar covalent compound. EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: SF‚ÇÑ is a non-polar molecule.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a non-polar molecule with individual bonds that are polar?
questions.explanation: CO‚ÇÇ is a non-polar molecule with polar bonds.

questions.text: Which bond between the following groups of elements will be the most polar?
questions.explanation: The S-F bond will be the most polar due to the high electronegativity difference between sulfur and fluorine.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the geometry of ICl‚ÇÑ‚Åª?
questions.explanation: The geometry of ICl‚ÇÑ‚Åª is square planar.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT true of metallic bonding?
options: It gives rise to excellent electrical conductivity
Electrons are free to move throughout the structure
The strength of metallic bonds increases down a group
The strength of metallic bonding affects the boiling points of metals
questions.explanation: The strength of metallic bonds generally decreases down a group.

questions.text: What type of hybridization is used by carbon in C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÇ (acetylene)?
questions.explanation: Carbon in acetylene (C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÇ) uses sp hybridization.

questions.text: Which molecule listed below has two sigma (œÉ) and two pi (œÄ) bonds?
questions.explanation: N‚ÇÇ has two sigma bonds and two pi bonds.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct rate equation for the given elementary reaction?
options: A + B + C ‚Üí P, Rate = K[A][C]
questions.explanation: The correct rate equation for the elementary reaction A + B ‚Üí P is Rate = K[A][B].

questions.text: Given the reaction: 2NO (g) + O‚ÇÇ (g) ‚Üí 2NO‚ÇÇ (g), Rate = K[NO]¬≤[O‚ÇÇ]. Which of the following is true if the pressure of NO is doubled?
options: The reaction rate increases by a factor of four
The reaction rate increases by a factor of two
The reaction rate increases by a factor of three
The reaction rate increases by a factor of eight
questions.explanation: If the pressure of NO is doubled, the reaction rate increases by a factor of four because the rate is proportional to [NO]¬≤.

questions.text: Which conditions generally will increase the rate of a chemical reaction?
options: Decreasing temperature and increasing concentration of the reactants.
Decreasing temperature and decreasing concentration of the reactants.
Increasing temperature and increasing concentration of the reactants.
Increasing temperature and decreasing concentration of the reactants.
questions.explanation: Increasing temperature and increasing concentration of the reactants generally increase the rate of a chemical reaction.

questions.text: What is the value of the rate constant (K) for a first-order reaction with a half-life of 3000 seconds?
questions.explanation: The rate constant for a first-order reaction is given by K = ln(2) / t‚ÇÅ/‚ÇÇ = ln(2) / 3000 ‚âà 2.31 x 10‚Åª‚Å¥.

questions.text: For a certain reaction, rate = k [A]. The rate when [A] = 0.60 M is
questions.explanation: The rate is directly proportional to the concentration of A. If the rate is 0.020 M/s when [A] = 1.0 M, then the rate when [A] = 0.60 M is 0.020 M/s * (0.60 M / 1.0 M) = 0.012 M/s.

questions.text: Which of the following is a termolecular reaction?
questions.explanation: The reaction 2HI ‚Üí H‚ÇÇ + I‚ÇÇ is a termolecular reaction.

questions.text: Which one of the following indicates the correct expression for the equilibrium constant (K)? PCl‚ÇÖ (s) ‚áå PCl‚ÇÉ (l) + Cl‚ÇÇ (g)
questions.explanation: The correct expression for the equilibrium constant (K) is [PCl‚ÇÉ][Cl‚ÇÇ] because solids and liquids do not appear in the expression for K.

questions.text: In the reaction; 2SO‚ÇÇ (g) + O‚ÇÇ (g) ‚áå 2SO‚ÇÉ (g), K=100. What is the [O‚ÇÇ], if the [SO‚ÇÇ] = [SO‚ÇÉ]?
questions.explanation: If [SO‚ÇÇ] = [SO‚ÇÉ], then K = [SO‚ÇÉ]¬≤ / ([SO‚ÇÇ]¬≤ [O‚ÇÇ]) = 100. Solving for [O‚ÇÇ] gives [O‚ÇÇ] = 0.1.

questions.text: The relation between the equilibrium constant in terms of concentration and pressure for the given reaction; 2NaHCO‚ÇÉ (s) ‚áå Na‚ÇÇCO‚ÇÉ (s) + H‚ÇÇO (g) + CO‚ÇÇ (g)
questions.explanation: The relation between the equilibrium constant in terms of concentration and pressure is Kp = KcRT.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a chemical reaction at equilibrium?
options: The concentrations of the products and reactants are equal
The rate of the forward reaction is less than the reverse reaction
The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the reverse reaction
The rate of the forward reaction is greater than the reverse reaction
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, the rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction.

questions.text: What is the degree of freedom, F for water, water vapor and ice in equilibrium?
questions.explanation: The degree of freedom (F) for water, water vapor, and ice in equilibrium is 1, according to the Gibbs phase rule.

questions.text: What is the chemical name for Aspirin?
questions.explanation: The chemical name for Aspirin is acetyl salicylic acid.

questions.text: What is the common name of the following structure?
questions.explanation: The common name of the structure is formic acid.

questions.text: What is the IUPAC name of CH‚ÇÉCOOCH‚ÇÇCH‚ÇÉ?
questions.explanation: The IUPAC name of CH‚ÇÉCOOCH‚ÇÇCH‚ÇÉ is ethylethanoate.

questions.text: Hydrolysis of propyl butanoate produces;
questions.explanation: Hydrolysis of propyl butanoate produces butanol and propanoic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning fats and oils is incorrect?
options: They are also called triacyl glycerols
questions.explanation: Fats and oils are not fatty acid salts; they are glycerol triesters.

questions.text: Which of the following types of compounds are expected products from the saponification of a fat?
options: Glycerol, fatty acids and fatty acid salts
Fatty acid salts and fatty acid
questions.explanation: The expected products from the saponification of a fat are glycerol and fatty acid salts.

questions.text: One of the following is true about acid and base?
options: Base is the substance when dissolved in water increases the [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫]
Acid is the substance when dissolved in water increases the [OH‚Åª]
questions.explanation: A base is a proton acceptor.

questions.text: What are the products in the self-ionization of water molecules?
questions.explanation: The products in the self-ionization of water molecules are H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ and OH‚Åª.

questions.text: The conjugate base of H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ is;
questions.explanation: The conjugate base of H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ is H‚ÇÇO.

questions.text: Given the reaction: H‚ÇÇPO‚ÇÑ‚Åª + H‚ÇÇO ‚áå H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ + HPO‚ÇÑ¬≤‚Åª. Which of the following represents a conjugate acid-base pair?
questions.explanation: H‚ÇÇPO‚ÇÑ‚Åª and H‚ÇÇO are a conjugate acid-base pair.

questions.text: The pOH of a 0.00008 M NaOH aqueous solution is;
questions.explanation: The pOH of a 0.00008 M NaOH aqueous solution is calculated as pOH = -log[OH‚Åª] = -log(0.00008) = 5.1.

questions.text: What is the pH of an aqueous solution in which [OH‚Åª] = 10‚Åª‚Å¥ [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] at 25 ‚ÑÉ?
questions.explanation: The pH of an aqueous solution in which [OH‚Åª] = 10‚Åª‚Å¥ [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] is calculated as pH = -log[H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] = -log(10‚Åª‚Å¥) = 4.

questions.text: What is the percent dissociation in 1M solution of HF containing the concentration of [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] = 2.7 √ó 10‚Åª¬≤ M?
questions.explanation: The percent dissociation is calculated as ([H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] / [HF]) * 100 = (2.7 √ó 10‚Åª¬≤ M / 1 M) * 100 = 2.7 %.

questions.text: The concentration of H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ and OH‚Åª respectively with pOH = 3 at 25‚àòC are
questions.explanation: With pOH = 3, [OH‚Åª] = 10‚Åª¬≥ M. The concentration of H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ is calculated as [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] = 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ / [OH‚Åª] = 10‚Åª¬π¬π M.

questions.text: Which of the following is a property of 1.0 M HCl but not a property of 1.0 M CH‚ÇÉCOOH?
questions.explanation: HCl ionizes completely in solution, while CH‚ÇÉCOOH is a weak acid and does not ionize completely.

questions.text: What is the pH and pOH of an aqueous solution at 25‚àòC if [H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] = 0.0004 M respectively
questions.explanation: The pH is calculated as pH = -log[H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫] = -log(0.0004) = 3.4. The pOH is calculated as pOH = 14 - pH = 14 - 3.4 = 10.6.

questions.text: What is the effect if 0.3 M of CH‚ÇÉCOONa is added into aqueous solution of 0.2 M CH‚ÇÉCOOH?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left
questions.explanation: Adding CH‚ÇÉCOONa to a solution of CH‚ÇÉCOOH will shift the equilibrium to the left, reducing the concentration of H‚ÇÉO‚Å∫ and increasing the pH.

questions.text: How is a buffer solution prepared?
options: By mixing a weak acid and a strong acid
By mixing a strong base and its conjugate acid
By mixing a strong acid and its conjugate base
By mixing a weak acid and its conjugate base
questions.explanation: A buffer solution is prepared by mixing a weak acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: The pOH of an aqueous solution which is created by adding 0.5 M NH‚ÇÉ and 0.5 M NH‚ÇÑCl (Kb NH‚ÇÉ = 1.8x10‚Åª‚Åµ)
questions.explanation: The pOH of the solution is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: In which of the following combination buffer solution possibly formed?
questions.explanation: A buffer solution is possibly formed by combining CH‚ÇÉCOOH and CH‚ÇÉCOONa.

questions.text: The Ka of benzoic acid is 6.30 x 10‚Åª‚Åµ. What is the pH of a buffer prepared by combining 50 ml of 1.0 M potassium benzoate and 50 ml of 1.0 M benzoic acid?
questions.explanation: The pH of the buffer is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a basic salt?
questions.explanation: HCOOK is a basic salt.

questions.text: Which one of the following hydrolysis of salt results in an acidic solution?
options: Weak acid and Salt of the weak acid
questions.explanation: The hydrolysis of a salt of a weak base and strong acid results in an acidic solution.

questions.text: The acid-base indicator methyl orange has a Ka of 1 x 10‚Åª‚Å∂. Its acidic form is red while its basic form is yellow. If methyl orange is added to a solution with a pH = 5, the color will be;
questions.explanation: At pH = 5, methyl orange will be in its acidic form, which is red. However, since the pH is close to the pKa, the color will be pink.

questions.text: Which of the following titration will have an equivalence point at a pH > 7?
questions.explanation: The titration of a strong acid with a weak base will have an equivalence point at a pH > 7.

questions.text: What volume of 0.2 M KOH is required to neutralize completely 50 mL of 1.5 M H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ?
questions.explanation: The volume of KOH required is calculated using the stoichiometry of the neutralization reaction.

questions.text: What is the normality of 0.3 M solution of Al‚ÇÇ(SO‚ÇÑ)‚ÇÉ?
questions.explanation: The normality of a 0.3 M solution of Al‚ÇÇ(SO‚ÇÑ)‚ÇÉ is calculated as 0.3 M * 6 eq/mol = 1.8 N.

questions.text: What is the molarity from complete ionization of 1.5N H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ?
questions.explanation: The molarity of a 1.5 N H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ solution is calculated as 1.5 N * 2 eq/mol = 3 M.

questions.text: Which of the following can conduct electricity?
questions.explanation: Salt solutions can conduct electricity due to the presence of ions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about electrolytic cells?
options: Redox reaction takes place in the cells
questions.explanation: In an electrolytic cell, the cathode is the positive electrode.

questions.text: The oxidation number of phosphorous is PO‚ÇÉ‚Åª is;
questions.explanation: The oxidation number of phosphorous in PO‚ÇÉ‚Åª is +5.

questions.text: In the reaction H‚ÇÇS(aq) + I‚ÇÇ(aq) ‚áå S(s) + 2H‚Å∫(aq) + 2I‚Åª(aq) the reducing agent is:
questions.explanation: H‚ÇÇS (aq) is the reducing agent because it is oxidized to S (s).

questions.text: One of the following is true in the electrolysis of brine solution?
options: NaOH is formed in the cell
questions.explanation: NaOH is formed in the cell during the electrolysis of brine solution.

questions.text: The products for the electrolysis of molten CuCl‚ÇÇ
options: O‚ÇÇ at anode and Cl‚ÇÇ at cathode
Cl‚ÇÇ at anode and H‚ÇÇ at cathode
Cu at anode and O‚ÇÇ at cathode
Cl‚ÇÇ at anode and Cu at cathode
questions.explanation: Cl‚ÇÇ is formed at the anode and Cu is formed at the cathode during the electrolysis of molten CuCl‚ÇÇ.

questions.text: For the electrolysis of an aqueous solution of Na‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ
options: O‚ÇÇ at cathode & H‚ÇÇ at anode are formed
H‚ÇÇ at cathode & O‚ÇÇ at anode are formed
Na at cathode & S‚ÇÇ at anode are formed
SO‚ÇÇ at cathode & Na at anode are formed
questions.explanation: H‚ÇÇ is formed at the cathode and O‚ÇÇ is formed at the anode during the electrolysis of an aqueous solution of Na‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ.

questions.text: From the electrolysis of aqueous solution of AgNO‚ÇÉ
options: NaOH is formed in the cell
questions.explanation: Ag is formed at the cathode during the electrolysis of an aqueous solution of AgNO‚ÇÉ.

questions.text: In the electrolysis of aqueous solution of copper sulphate using active copper electrode;
questions.explanation: Cu (s) ‚Üí Cu¬≤‚Å∫ (aq) + 2e is the correct reaction at the anode during the electrolysis of aqueous solution of copper sulphate using active copper electrode.

questions.text: What mass of Mg is formed by passing a current of 0.965 A through molten MgCl‚ÇÇ for a period of 100 seconds (24ùëÄùëî, F=96500 ùëê )
questions.explanation: The mass of Mg formed is calculated using Faraday's law of electrolysis.

questions.text: What is the mass of Aluminium deposited by the electrolysis of aqueous solution Al‚ÇÇ(SO‚ÇÑ)‚ÇÉ placed in series with AgNO‚ÇÉ aqueous solution when 10.8 g of Ag is deposited? (Molar mass of Ag=108, Al=27)
questions.explanation: The mass of Aluminium deposited is calculated using the stoichiometry of the electrolysis reactions.

questions.text: The volume of O‚ÇÇ formed at STP when OH‚Åª is oxidized by passing 100A in 965 seconds?
questions.explanation: The volume of O‚ÇÇ formed is calculated using the stoichiometry of the reaction and the ideal gas law.

questions.text: All of the following is the uses of electrolysis. Except;
questions.explanation: Electrolysis is not used for the production of electricity.

questions.text: All of the following is the uses of electroplating. Except;
options: Increase the beauty of the metals
Increase the reaction at the cathode
Increase the strength of the metals
questions.explanation: Electroplating does not increase the reaction at the cathode.

questions.text: Consider the standard voltaic cell, which answer identifies the cathode and gives the E¬∞? Given E¬∞red (Au‚Å∫¬≥/Au=1.50 v, Fe‚Å∫¬≤/Fe= - 0.44v)
questions.explanation: The cathode is Au with E¬∞ = 1.50 V - (-0.44 V) = 1.94 V.

questions.text: Which one of the following is true about Galvanic cell?
options: Anode is positive terminal and the place where oxidation occurs
Cathode is the negative terminal and the place where reduction occurs
Electron flows from cathode terminal to anode terminal
Chemical energy is converted to electrical energy
questions.explanation: In a Galvanic cell, chemical energy is converted to electrical energy.

questions.text: Given the reaction: x(s) + y¬≤‚Å∫(aq) ‚Üí x¬≤‚Å∫(aq) + y(s). What is the correct representation of the cell notation?
questions.explanation: The correct representation of the cell notation is x(s) / x¬≤‚Å∫(aq) // y¬≤‚Å∫(aq) / y(s).

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about automobile batteries?
options: It is an example of primary cells
questions.explanation: H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ is used as the electrolyte in automobile batteries.
